description: From French claque (“group of people hired to applaud or boo, claque”, literally “a slap; a clap”), from claquer (“of hands: to clap”) (paying audience members to applaud having started at the Paris Opera), ultimately from Proto-Germanic *klakōną (“to clap; to clack; to chirp, tweet, twitter”), from Proto-Indo-European *glag- (“to make a noise; to chatter, chirp”).

entries.meaning: (collective) A group of people hired to attend a performance and to either applaud or boo.
A group of people who pre-arrange among themselves to express strong support for an idea, so as to give the false impression of a wider consensus.
